utterances: You know, I think it goes back to happily.
And I think Malmo, Sweden probably has more in common with a Denver or a San Jose than it does with a rural area in the middle of America or Sweden.

And I find this quite challenging because I do believe that our society is - my friend Bill Bishop wrote this remarkable book, ""The Big Sort."" Our societies are sorting people with ambition, with means, with talent, are clustering in urban centers, and many other people are being left behind in more rural areas and parts of the country.
So yes, I think we're talking about these mega-regions that are culturally and sociologically - not only economically similar, but they're similar in terms of lifestyle and people's attitude.
So yes, I think it's easier, certainly than it was 20 or 30 years ago, to move across the peaks of the world economy.

We're talking with Richard Florida about his book ""Who's Your City?: How the Creative Economy Is Making Where to Live the Most Important Decision of Your Life."" And you're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Let's go to Jan. Jan's with us from Hilton Head in South Carolina.
Yes.
And thank you so much for taking my call.
I had something I wanted to say, but I wanted to preface this with I've lived in Denmark.
I lived, actually, in North Aarhus.
And you have to get used to living a good part of your life with no light, because come wintertime, the peak of winter, there is no light from morning until night.
And part of the reason that I left Denmark was that there were certain things I could not acclimate.
But this actually has nothing to do with why I called.
I've just been sitting on the phone listening to you, I thought I would just comment that.
And it's also a book that focuses on all - many of the world class writers that I interviewed.
I've been privileged and lucky enough to interview - like you, of course, I interview different people everydayâ€¦
I'm a medically trained massage therapist and moved to Hilton Head out in South Carolina because it is a resort area and it's very good for people who are very talented in massage and such.
But I am spiritually starved, I am emotionally starved, I'm living in the White Bright capital of the United States, and it's all pretty and there's a lovely beach and people are polite.
But there is a certain quality to life that I'm starving for that I'm not getting here.
And I'm a person who grew up in Washington, D.C.
A picture from me from the '60s is very well known.
I'm the girl that's holding the flower when the soldiers are pointing their rifles at me.
We've all seen that picture.
Go ahead.
Yeah, yeah.
But I'm somebody who's been very involved and who's been involved in political processes and this and that.
And I do some community service here, but basically it's like beating my head against the wall to try and motivate people.
People are very self-satisfied here.
And where are you thinking about moving, Jan?
Well, quite honestly, I've had an inspiration lately because I do feel like I have an important voice.
And I'm seriously thinking about Los Angeles.
And I'm thinking about doing stand-up comedy, but comedy with conscience.
Making a good decision, do you think, Richard?
I think Los Angeles would be a great place for you.
And the book talks about these personality types, and we mentioned it a couple of minutes ago.
But this young, fellow Jason Rentfrow(ph), he's truly a genius in psychology.
We know that there are five personality types, and I know your one just listening to you.
There's conscientious people, there's extroverts, there's agreeable people, there's emotionally stable or conversely neurotic people - you're not that.
And there's a group of people who are many of the callers, called open to experience.
Yes.
Open to experience people, when we map them, and they're on the maps in the book at the web site.
They are like pinpoints on a map of New York, Washington, Boston, Seattle, LA, San Francisco.
Open to experience people need new energy.
They need diverse experiences.
They need to be about exciting environments naturally, socially.
And what we're finding is that it's not like you're going out and saying, I want to find open to experience people.
You're looking and searching for a place that has that environment with others like you.
Los Angeles is one of the top destinations.
And just finally, when you said light, one of the things we found is that so many people are drawn to natural environments that are not only light but have blues and greens.
So from everything you're saying, you are an open to experience kind of person.
And the other thing, finally, Neal, you'll get a kick out.
Jason has identified the NPR listener as a specific subset of the open to experience person in his research.
So I think the callers reflect that, but there are a group of regions that we talk about in the book that are a better fit.
And although I like vacationing in Hilton, it is not the best for someone with your personality.
Well, I have to bow to your wisdom because most of my life I've identified myself as more experiential.
And I go in for the - I really try to dig in the meat of life.
I really try to live life to the fullest, but with a conscience.
My social consciousness is my number one raison d'etre in life.
Jan...
But you're really on the money.
You're amazing.
Good luck to you, Jan. Appreciate the phone call.
Thanks so much.
Richard Florida, stay with us if you would.
We're going to take some more calls after a short break.
And we're also going to be talking about Tiger Woods, maybe the most famous knee in the country right now.
We'll talk about his surgery, and well, the dominance that he's had in his sport.
Amazing finish at the Open this past week.
I'm Neal Conan.
Stay with us.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
In just a couple of minutes we're going to be talking with Chip Brown, who wrote a piece for the New York Times Magazine about Tiger Woods.

But now, let's continue our conversation with Richard Florida about his new book,""Who's Your City?: How The Creative Economy Is Making Where To Live The Most Important Decision Of Your Life."" And let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
This is Carry(ph).
Carry with us from San Antonio in Texas.
Hello!
Hi, Carrie.
You're on the air.
Oh, thank you.
I am here in San Antonio.
My husband is an army physician, and we are one year away from ending his commitment to the Army.
And we've always been - I've always been excited about being able to pick wherever we'd like to live.
And now we're thinking about it and it is so hard to try to figure this out.
We do have young children, and we like San Antonio, there's a lot to do here.
But we find our kids - we have to drive 30, 40 minutes to get to a park that's shady and safe for them.
And it is a big, sprawling city now.
Where would you suggest that we look?
Well, you have to take a Place Finder.
I mean, that's the first thing you have to do on the web site at whosyourcity.com.
You have to do it.
But for families with children, quite strikingly, and I'm looking at our list - this is overall, not saying it'll fit you.
Number one is the Washington, D.C.
region.
Number two is Boston.
Number three is San Jose.
Number four is New York Metro, not just the city.
Number five is San Diego.
Then we have smaller ones.
So those would be some to consider.
Smaller places, a place like Ventura, California, probably North Carolina, Provo, Utah, Boulder, Colorado.
But the key is, what's the place that fits you and your family best?
And that's what we tried to do in the Place Finder.
That's what we call questions.
You take them, you put in some city names, some suburb names, and it tries to generate a profile of a place that you would like, possibly like, and fit the best.
Carrie, I'd think it would be a tremendous risk.
Your kids might turn out to be Red Sox Fans, you know?
Just awful.
(Soundbite of laughter)
There are worse things, even for a New Yorker.
The idea, though, your husband's a physician.
You can move, I would think, just about anywhere you want.
Sure.
Yeah, the ears are similar on the two.
And the thing that I was - I'm sorry, the thing I was so amazed by was that no one is willing to give people this advice.
And that's why I tell the story about my editor, saying, I give advice.
And my friends saying, you can't write self-help, you can't give advice.
Well, I said, no one has ever done this.
And as we're hearing from all the callers, it's almost like we have too much choice.
And let's try to make it a little bit more rational and simpler and straightforward.
And this is exactly why I tried to write the book.
And hopefully you'll find it helpful.
Good luck, Carry.
Thank you.
All right.

Bye.
